Not the quality you'd expect from a reputable publisher. The idea is half-baked, the combat clunky, the controls jittery, the voice acting C-grade, and the entire plot so incredibly inept that it makes you want to claw your eyes out.
BioShock 2 was buggy, but this is a nightmare of game-breaking bugs and poor development. Feels like it tried to approach the topics of racism and classism while targeting a steampunk FPS audience, ultimately failing at both.
The game itself has no redeeming value and could be finished by a blind quadriplegic before the return period expires. Unfinished, poorly made, unnecessary.
You aren't missing anything. Forget this game exists. Let Bioshock die in peace. Don't have this mess tacked onto its good name.

0/10 - Terrible price. Terrible game. Dumpster fire.

I'm not into linear games. I enjoy free world, like Skyrim and BOTW. So when i saw Cryaotic play this game, i didn't really want it that bad. But as time went on i rewatched his playthrough a couple times and fell in love with the game. So i got it and even while i knew what to expect, i still felt surprised at the ending, speechless. While i would prefer better graphics and not so picture-print kind of quality, it still blew my mind and i recommend it!

IQ 141 이상 - 4ra 4ra try try no regret. 너님이라면 한방에 이해하겠지.

IQ 121 ~ 140 - 곳곳에 숨겨진 복선, 의미 없는 것은 없다. 그러니 잘 관찰하도록.

IQ 101 ~ 120 - 스토리가 헷갈리겠지만 아무래도 좋음. 1회차 클리어 뒤 인터넷에서 스토리 모음들 보면 소름 쫘악.

IQ 90 ~ 100 - 괜찮아. 엘리자베스가 있잖아.

IQ 80 ~ 89 - 스팀펑크 좋아하면 하세요.

The third installment of the "Bioshock" Franchise: "Bioshock Infinite." This time, we're in the majestic floating city of Columbia. There are new mechanics to learn; there are more enemies to kill. No, it isn't the underwater city of Rapture we're used to, but this one takes us on a journey that is not like the others -- this has a special new story to be remembered.

Diversas mecánica.  Siempre en cambio.  Sorpresas a lo largo del juego. Te anima a volver a jugar.

Ademas tu acompañante en la historia es de las mejores. No te sentirás sólo en tu travesía.

Bioshock Infinite is well worth its price. I played this game without having played the earlier Bioshock or Bioshock 2, so I am reviewing it as a standalone game after my playthrough on hard mode.

Pros:
- The story is top-notch, and even though I did not fully understand it (which is partially the point), I was very engaged with it. The twist at the end is crazy.
- At first I thought the death system (everytime you die you lose some money, you get some ammo, and enemies get health back) to be a stupid idea that took away the challenge, but I actually felt much more determined not to die because of this penalty, and it also made me think more about money management. It only made me want to slam my head into a brick wall once ([spoiler]in the first Lady Comstock battle before I understood how to much more easily fight her[/spoiler]).
- Resource management is well approached. I often felt like I had to vary up weapons to conserve ammo.
- Combat feels challenging, engaging, and varied. Weapons each feel unique, and each of the vigors have fun, varying effects. Elizabeth's tear abilities help to make the combat even more satisfying, as she tosses you exactly the resources you needed mid-battle.
- You can really sense yourself becoming substantially better at the game as you continue playing.
- Columbia is colorful and aesthetically varied while the art style still manages to follow a certain motif.
- Robot George Washington can fight Robot Abe Lincoln.

Cons:
- Before the final third of the game, gunplay often requires you to hide behind walls and wait a while to regain shield. Then, you get a vigor that allows you to temporarily block all damage, and, if you play like me, you rarely use any of the other vigors. I also felt no need to change gear very often.
- The Handymen (Infinite's version of the Big Daddy) can feel more like a chore to fight than a formidable enemy.
- Storywise, vigors make no sense in Columbia, as well as scavenging through trash cans to find weapon ammo.
- The game feels just a bit too repetitive for me to want to play it on the more difficult 1999 mode.

Bioshock Infinite is well worth its price. I played this game without having played the earlier Bioshock or Bioshock 2, so I am reviewing it as a standalone game after my playthrough on hard mode.

Pros:
- The story is top-notch, and even though I did not fully understand it (which is partially the point), I was very engaged with it. The twist at the end is crazy.
- At first I thought the death system (everytime you die you lose some money, you get some ammo, and enemies get health back) to be a stupid idea that took away the challenge, but I actually felt much more determined not to die because of this penalty, and it also made me think more about money management. It only made me want to slam my head into a brick wall once ([spoiler]in the first Lady Comstock battle before I understood how to much more easily fight her[/spoiler]).
- Resource management is well approached. I often felt like I had to vary up weapons to conserve ammo.
- Combat feels challenging, engaging, and varied. Weapons each feel unique, and each of the vigors have fun, varying effects. Elizabeth's tear abilities help to make the combat even more satisfying, as she tosses you exactly the resources you needed mid-battle.
- You can really sense yourself becoming substantially better at the game as you continue playing.
- Columbia is colorful and aesthetically varied while the art style still manages to follow a certain motif.
- Robot George Washington can fight Robot Abe Lincoln.

Cons:
- Before the final third of the game, gunplay often requires you to hide behind walls and wait a while to regain shield. Then, you get a vigor that allows you to temporarily block all damage, and, if you play like me, you rarely use any of the other vigors. I also felt no need to change gear very often.
- The Handymen (Infinite's version of the Big Daddy) can feel more like a chore to fight than a formidable enemy.
- Storywise, vigors make no sense in Columbia, as well as scavenging through trash cans to find weapon ammo.
- The game feels just a bit too repetitive for me to want to play it on the more difficult 1999 mode.

PS: I might have played about half the game unknowingly having equipped a gear that took 25% of my damage away when hip firing weapons. Don't make the same mistake that I did.
